context: [8] Alternatively, NO can inhibits Oâ¨ª2 production by the modification of the activity of NADPH oxidase, the main enzyme that generates Oâ¨ª2 within the cell . [1] Further, we have found that the addition of NO donors to TNF-Î±-stimulated AD10 cells inhibited either the DNA binding activity of NF-ÎºB (Fig. 3) or its activation (Fig. 5). [2] This inhibition was restored to the normal H2O2-stimulated level by treatment with exogenous H2O2. [3] In contrast, nitric oxide did not affect the NF-ÎºB activation in untreated AD10 cells, confirming the previous observation with TNF-Î± gene expression. [4] These results suggest the presence of at least two pathways in the activation of NF-ÎºB in AD10 cells that may differ in their sensitivity to H2O2 and the selectivity of nitric oxide to affect just one of these two pathways. [5] The inactivation of NF-ÎºB upon NO treatment was not mediated by guanylate cyclase activation since the cGMP analogue 8-bromo-cGMP had no effect on NF-ÎºB and we could not block the inhibitory effect of NO on NF-ÎºB activation by the use of the guanylate cyclase blocker 1H-(1,2,4)oxadiazolo-[4,3-a]quinoxalin-1-one (data not shown). [1] Previous reports have implicated the role of nitric oxide on the activation of NF-ÎºB.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) is shown to influence gene expression by inhibiting the activation of NF-κB in TNF-α-stimulated AD10 cells. The study indicates that NO can selectively affect one of the pathways involved in NF-κB activation, suggesting a regulatory role of NO in gene expression related to inflammatory responses. The findings highlight the complex interactions between NO and gene expression mechanisms, particularly in the context of oxidative stress and inflammation.
